question: What are the documents required to be submitted before submission deadline? List all of them and indicate how to prepare these docs.
answer:
Below is a practical “check‑list” of every document that a typical research‑grant application (e.g., a national R&D grant, a European Horizon‑style call, or a U.S. NIH/NSF proposal) requires, together with a short guide on how to prepare each item.  
Feel free to adapt the wording and the page‑limits to the specific call you are targeting.

---

## 1.  Application Form / Cover Sheet  
| What to include | How to prepare |
|-----------------|----------------|
| • Applicant’s name, title, and contact details | Use the template supplied by the funding body; keep it neat and double‑check spelling. |
| • Project title (≤ 50 chars) | Make it concise, descriptive, and keyword‑rich. |
| • Funding programme / call number | Copy exactly from the call announcement. |
| • Applicant’s institution and department | Include the official institutional address. |
| • Principal Investigator (PI) signature | Sign electronically or print‑out and scan. |
| • Submission date | Leave blank; the portal will auto‑populate. |

> **Tip:** Keep the form in a separate PDF file named *[PI‑Surname]_[ProjectTitle]_Cover.pdf*.

---

## 2.  Project Summary / Abstract (≈ 500 words)  
| What to include | How to prepare |
|-----------------|----------------|
| • Research question / hypothesis | State it in one sentence. |
| • Objectives / aims | List 3–5 clear, measurable aims. |
| • Methodology (brief) | Summarise the main approach and key techniques. |
| • Expected outcomes | Highlight novelty, impact, and potential applications. |
| • Timeline & milestones | Provide a 3‑year snapshot. |
| • Budget overview | Mention total budget and major cost categories. |

> **Tip:** Write the summary *after* the full proposal so you can capture the most important points. Use a 12‑pt Times New Roman or Arial font, single‑spaced, with 1.5 line spacing.

---

## 3.  Detailed Project Proposal (5–10 pages)  
| Section | Content | How to prepare |
|---------|---------|----------------|
| **Background & Significance** | Literature review, knowledge gap, societal relevance | Use recent (≤ 5 yr) peer‑reviewed sources; cite properly. |
| **Objectives & Hypotheses** | Specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, time‑bound (SMART) | Align with the summary. |
| **Methodology** | Experimental design, data collection, analysis plan, tools | Include flowcharts or diagrams if helpful. |
| **Expected Results & Impact** | Anticipated findings, contribution to field, translational potential | Quantify where possible. |
| **Timeline & Work Plan** | Gantt chart or table of tasks, responsible persons, deliverables | Use a simple table; avoid overly detailed day‑by‑day plans. |
| **Budget Justification** | Link each budget line to a specific activity | Provide a brief narrative for each major cost. |
| **Risk Management & Contingency** | Identify risks, mitigation strategies | Show you have thought through potential pitfalls. |
| **Ethics & Data Management** | IRB approvals, data sharing plan, privacy safeguards | Attach ethics approval letters if required. |
| **References** | APA/Harvard style, no more than 30 key references | Keep it concise. |

> **Tip:** Use a consistent heading style (e.g., Heading 1 for main sections, Heading 2 for subsections). Save the file as *[PI‑Surname]_[ProjectTitle]_Proposal.docx* and export to PDF for submission.

---

## 4.  Budget (Itemised)  
| Item | Description | How to prepare |
|------|-------------|----------------|
| **Personnel** | Salaries, stipends, fringe benefits | Provide a table with roles, % effort, and cost. |
| **Equipment** | Major instruments, software licenses | Justify necessity; include purchase or lease details. |
| **Consumables** | Reagents, lab supplies, travel | Estimate based on similar projects. |
| **Travel** | Conferences, fieldwork, collaboration visits | Include per‑diem, airfare, accommodation. |
| **Indirect Costs** | Overhead, institutional fees | Use the institution’s approved rate. |
| **Other** | Publication fees, patent filing, outreach | Provide brief justification. |

> **Tip:** Use the funding body’s budget template if available. Keep the total budget within the call’s ceiling.

---

## 5.  Curriculum Vitae (CV) of the PI & Key Personnel  
| What to include | How to prepare |
|-----------------|----------------|
| • Education (degrees, institutions, dates) | List in reverse chronological order. |
| • Research experience | Highlight projects, roles, and outcomes. |
| • Publications | List top 10 recent peer‑reviewed papers; include impact factor. |
| • Grants & Funding | Summarise previous awards, amounts, and outcomes. |
| • Teaching & Mentoring | Briefly note courses taught, supervision of PhD/masters. |
| • Technical & Soft Skills | List relevant software, languages, leadership roles. |
| • Professional Memberships | Include any relevant societies. |

> **Tip:** Keep the CV to 2–3 pages. Use a clean, professional layout (e.g., Times New Roman 11 pt, single‑spaced).

---

## 6.  Letters of Support / Collaboration  
| Who should write | What to include | How to prepare |
|------------------|-----------------|----------------|
| **Collaborating Institutions** | Statement of commitment, resources to be provided, role in project | Provide a template; ask the collaborator to sign and stamp. |
| **Funding Agencies (if applicable)** | Confirmation of co‑funding or in‑kind support | Attach official letter. |
| **Ethics Committees** | Approval of study protocols | Attach the signed approval letter. |

> **Tip:** Each letter should be no longer than one page, signed by a senior official, and include the institution’s letterhead.

---

## 7.  Ethics Approval / IRB Documentation  
| What to include | How to prepare |
|-----------------|----------------|
| • IRB/ethics committee approval letter | Ensure it covers all study sites and participant groups. |
| • Consent forms (if applicable) | Attach a copy of the participant information sheet and consent form. |

> **Tip:** If the study is purely computational, a statement of exemption may suffice.

---

## 8.  Data Management Plan (DMP)  
| What to include | How to prepare |
|-----------------|----------------|
| • Data types & formats | Specify file types, metadata standards. |
| • Storage & backup | Outline secure storage, backup frequency, retention period. |
| • Sharing & access | Describe repositories, embargo periods, licensing. |
| • Privacy & security | Detail anonymisation, encryption, compliance with GDPR/FERPA. |

> **Tip:** Many funding bodies provide a DMP template; use it verbatim.

---

## 9.  Conflict of Interest Statement  
| What to include | How to prepare |
|-----------------|----------------|
| • Disclosure of any financial or personal interests | Be transparent; include a brief statement. |
| • Mitigation plan | Explain how potential conflicts will be managed. |

> **Tip:** Keep it concise (≤ 200 words).

---

## 10.  Proof of Institutional Affiliation  
| What to include | How to prepare |
|-----------------|----------------|
| • Letter from department chair or dean | Confirm your appointment, research status, and availability. |
| • Institutional seal or stamp | Ensure the letter is on official letterhead. |

> **Tip:** Some calls require a signed and dated letter; check the exact wording.

---

## 11.  Optional / Supplementary Documents  
| Document | When to include | How to prepare |
|----------|-----------------|----------------|
| • Patents / IP filings | If the project builds on existing IP | Attach copies or summaries. |
| • Prior publications / conference posters | To demonstrate expertise | Provide a short list (≤ 5). |
| • Preliminary data | To strengthen feasibility | Include a brief summary or figures. |

> **Tip:** Only attach if explicitly requested or if it adds clear value.

---

## 12.  Final Checklist Before Submission  
1. **All PDFs are password‑protected?** – No, most portals require open PDFs.  
2. **Page numbers & consistent formatting?** – Yes.  
3. **All required attachments present?** – Verify against the call’s “Required Documents” list.  
4. **No spelling or grammatical errors?** – Run a spell‑check and have a colleague proofread.  
5. **Budget totals match the call’s ceiling?** – Double‑check calculations.  
6. **Submission portal login & test upload?** – Do a dry run.  
7. **Backup copies saved?** – Store in a secure cloud folder and on a local drive.  
8. **Deadline confirmed?** – Note the exact time (often 23:59 UTC).  

> **Final tip:** Submit at least 48 h before the deadline to avoid last‑minute technical glitches.

---

### Quick Reference File Naming Convention  
| Document | File Name Example |
|----------|-------------------|
| Cover Sheet | *Smith_QuantumSensors_Cover.pdf* |
| Summary | *Smith_QuantumSensors_Summary.pdf* |
| Proposal | *Smith_QuantumSensors_Proposal.docx* |
| Budget | *Smith_QuantumSensors_Budget.xlsx* |
| CV | *Smith_CV.pdf* |
| Letters | *Collab_UniversityA_Letter.pdf* |
| Ethics | *IRB_Approval.pdf* |
| DMP | *DMP_QuantumSensors.pdf* |
| Conflict | *COI_Statement.pdf* |
| Affiliation | *Affiliation_Letter.pdf* |

---

**Good luck with your application!**  
If you need help tailoring any of these documents to a specific funding body, let me know and I can provide more detailed guidance.
